[[File:Tahrir Square April 8 2011.png|thumb||Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 8 April 2011]]
+
[[File:Tahrir Square on April 8 2011.jpg|thumb||Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 8 April 2011]]
'''25 January 2011''': The '''"Day of Revolt"''': Protests erupted throughout Egypt, with tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Cairo and thousands more in cities throughout Egypt. The protests targeted President Hosni Mubarak's government, and mostly adhered to non-violence. There were some reports of civilian and police casualties.
'''25 January 2011''': The '''"Day of Revolt"''': Protests erupted throughout Egypt, with tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Cairo and thousands more in cities throughout Egypt. The protests targeted President Hosni Mubarak's government, and mostly adhered to non-violence. There were some reports of civilian and police casualties.
Line 567: Line 567:
{{see|Egyptian Armed Forces}}
{{see|Egyptian Armed Forces}}
[[File:Abrams in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|An [[M1 Abrams]] tank of the Egyptian Army deployed in Cairo during the revolution]]
[[File:Abrams in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|An [[M1 Abrams]] tank of the Egyptian Army deployed in Cairo during the revolution]]
  +
[[File:Burning amy vehicle.png|thumb||One of the 2 army vehicles that were burned during the massive army attacks that happened on April 9, 2011.]]
The [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] enjoy a better reputation with the public than the police does, the former perceived as a professional body protecting the country, the latter accused of systemic corruption and illegitimate violence. All four [[Egyptian president]]s since the 1950s have come from the military into power. Key Egyptian military personnel include the Defense Minister [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] and General [[Sami Hafez Enan]], Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LC1NLO0.html |title=Key members of Egypt Armed Forces Supreme Council |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=[[Ian Black (journalist)|Black, Ian]]|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-military-hosni-mubarak|title=All Eyes on Egypt's Military as Hosni Mubarak Fortifies Position |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011 |location=London}}</ref> The Egyptian military totals around 468,500 well-armed active personnel, plus a reserve of 479,000.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/30/uk-egypt-protests-military-idUKTRE70T29420110130|title=Factbox â Egypt's Powerful Military|work=[[Reuters]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
The [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] enjoy a better reputation with the public than the police does, the former perceived as a professional body protecting the country, the latter accused of systemic corruption and illegitimate violence. All four [[Egyptian president]]s since the 1950s have come from the military into power. Key Egyptian military personnel include the Defense Minister [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] and General [[Sami Hafez Enan]], Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LC1NLO0.html |title=Key members of Egypt Armed Forces Supreme Council |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=[[Ian Black (journalist)|Black, Ian]]|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-military-hosni-mubarak|title=All Eyes on Egypt's Military as Hosni Mubarak Fortifies Position |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011 |location=London}}</ref> The Egyptian military totals around 468,500 well-armed active personnel, plus a reserve of 479,000.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/30/uk-egypt-protests-military-idUKTRE70T29420110130|title=Factbox â Egypt's Powerful Military|work=[[Reuters]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
As Head of Egypt's Armed Forces, Tantawi has been described as "aged and change-resistant" and is attached to the old regime. He has used his position as Defense Minister to oppose reforms, economic and political, which he saw as weakening central government authority. Other key figures, Sami Enan chief among them, are younger and have closer connections to both the US and groups such as the Muslim Brotherhood. An important aspect of the relationship between the Egyptian and American military establishments is the 1.3 billion dollars in military aid provided to Egypt annually, which in turn pays for American-made military equipment, and allows Egyptian officers to receive training in the US. Guaranteed this aid package, the governing [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|military council]] is for the most reform-resistant.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/14/wikileaks-cables-egyptian-military-head |title=WikiLeaks cables: Egyptian military head is 'old and resistant to change' |publisher=The Guardian |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |location=London |first1=Julian |last1=Borger |first2=James |last2=Ball}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/feb/04/egypt-arms-trade?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 |title=Egypt's military-industrial complex |publisher=The Guardian |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |location=London |first=Pratap |last=Chatterjee}}</ref> One analyst however, while conceding that the military is change-resistant, states it has no option but to facilitate the process of democratisation. Furthermore, the military will have to keep its role in politics limited to continue good relations with the West, and must not restrict the participation of political Islam if there is to be a genuine democracy.<ref name="Shlomo Ben Ari"/>
As Head of Egypt's Armed Forces, Tantawi has been described as "aged and change-resistant" and is attached to the old regime. He has used his position as Defense Minister to oppose reforms, economic and political, which he saw as weakening central government authority. Other key figures, Sami Enan chief among them, are younger and have closer connections to both the US and groups such as the Muslim Brotherhood. An important aspect of the relationship between the Egyptian and American military establishments is the 1.3 billion dollars in military aid provided to Egypt annually, which in turn pays for American-made military equipment, and allows Egyptian officers to receive training in the US. Guaranteed this aid package, the governing [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|military council]] is for the most reform-resistant.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/14/wikileaks-cables-egyptian-military-head |title=WikiLeaks cables: Egyptian military head is 'old and resistant to change' |publisher=The Guardian |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |location=London |first1=Julian |last1=Borger |first2=James |last2=Ball}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/feb/04/egypt-arms-trade?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 |title=Egypt's military-industrial complex |publisher=The Guardian |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |location=London |first=Pratap |last=Chatterjee}}</ref> One analyst however, while conceding that the military is change-resistant, states it has no option but to facilitate the process of democratisation. Furthermore, the military will have to keep its role in politics limited to continue good relations with the West, and must not restrict the participation of political Islam if there is to be a genuine democracy.<ref name="Shlomo Ben Ari"/>

===Online activism===
+
===Online activism and the role of social media===
[[We are all Khaled Said|We Are All Khaled Saeed]] is a [[Facebook]] group which formed in the aftermath of Saeed's beating and death. The group attracted hundreds of thousands of members worldwide and played a prominent role in spreading and bringing attention to the growing discontent. As the protests began, Google executive [[Wael Ghonim]] revealed that he was the person behind the account.<ref>{{cite news|title = Who is Wael Ghonim?|date = 8 February 2011|publisher = [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|url = http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/08/f-wael-ghonim.html|work = CBC News|accessdate = 17 February 2011}}</ref> Another potent viral online contribution was made by [[Asmaa Mahfouz]], a female activist who posted a video in which she challenged people to publicly protest.<ref>{{cite news|title = Women play vital role in Egypt's uprising|url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising|date = 4 February 2011|work = National Public Radio|format = transcript|accessdate = 6 February 2011}}</ref> Previously, Facebook had suspended the group because some of its administrators were using pseudonyms, a violation of the company's 'Terms of Service.'<ref>{{cite news|title = Can Egypt's Internet Movement Be Exported?|date = 18 February 2011|publisher = [[The Nation]]|url = http://www.thenation.com/print/article/158717/can-egypts-internet-movement-be-exported|work = The Nation|accessdate = 23 February 2011}}</ref>
[[We are all Khaled Said|We Are All Khaled Saeed]] is a [[Facebook]] group which formed in the aftermath of Saeed's beating and death. The group attracted hundreds of thousands of members worldwide and played a prominent role in spreading and bringing attention to the growing discontent. As the protests began, Google executive [[Wael Ghonim]] revealed that he was the person behind the account.<ref>{{cite news|title = Who is Wael Ghonim?|date = 8 February 2011|publisher = [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|url = http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/08/f-wael-ghonim.html|work = CBC News|accessdate = 17 February 2011}}</ref> Another potent viral online contribution was made by [[Asmaa Mahfouz]], a female activist who posted a video in which she challenged people to publicly protest.<ref>{{cite news|title = Women play vital role in Egypt's uprising|url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising|date = 4 February 2011|work = National Public Radio|format = transcript|accessdate = 6 February 2011}}</ref> Previously, Facebook had suspended the group because some of its administrators were using pseudonyms, a violation of the company's 'Terms of Service.'<ref>{{cite news|title = Can Egypt's Internet Movement Be Exported?|date = 18 February 2011|publisher = [[The Nation]]|url = http://www.thenation.com/print/article/158717/can-egypts-internet-movement-be-exported|work = The Nation|accessdate = 23 February 2011}}</ref>

===Role of social media===
 
It is readily believed that a hand full of people through [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], and blogging sparked this uprising. One of which is [[Wael Ghonim]] . Many believe Ghonim was the first contributor to spark the Egypt revolution when he created a [[Facebook]] page dedicated to a Kaled blank entitled [[We are all Khaled Said|We Are All Khaled Saeed]] . Said, an Egyptian business man was beaten to death by police in June 2010. It is believed that this was in retaliation to a video he posted showing Egyptian police sharing the spoils of a drug bust. The [[Facebook]] page blew up to over 400,000 followers, creating an online arena where protestors and those discontent with the government could gather, vent, and organise. The page called for protests on 25 January, Known as the day of wrath. Hundreds of thousands of protestors flooded the streets to show their discontent with the murder and the corruption within their country. Ghonim was jailed the 28th and released 12 days later. Ghonim has also gained quiet a large following through his Twitter account where he has been creating a narrative of the events happening day to day in Egypt. Ghonim is the Middle East and North African marketing manager at Google. He is currently on leave.

Many believe Ghonim was the first contributor to spark the Egypt revolution when he created a [[Facebook]] page dedicated to a Kaled blank entitled [[We are all Khaled Said|We Are All Khaled Saeed]] . Said, an Egyptian business man was beaten to death by police in June 2010. It is believed that this was in retaliation to a video he posted showing Egyptian police sharing the spoils of a drug bust. The [[Facebook]] page blew up to over 400,000 followers, creating an online arena where protestors and those discontent with the government could gather, vent, and organise. The page called for protests on 25 January, Known as the day of wrath. Hundreds of thousands of protestors flooded the streets to show their discontent with the murder and the corruption within their country. Ghonim was jailed the 28th and released 12 days later. Ghonim has also gained quiet a large following through his Twitter account where he has been creating a narrative of the events happening day to day in Egypt. Ghonim is the Middle East and North African marketing manager at Google. He is currently on leave.
